title: My three generations never paid farm electricity bills: Shiv Sena MP
desc: Union minister Prataprao Jadhav revealed that his family has not paid farm electricity bills for three generations. Speaking at an event for the Chief Minister Baliraja Free Electricity Scheme 2024, he mentioned giving money to engineers to replace burnt distribution panels. The scheme offers free electricity to farmers using pumps up to 7.5 horsepower.

title: Government seeks explanation from edible oil companies on rising prices
desc: The government has asked edible oil firms to explain the rise in retail prices despite adequate stocks imported at lower duties. The Centre had increased customs duty on various edible oils to support domestic farmers, but urged firms to maintain stable prices during the festival season. Stocks should last 45-50 days, officials said.

title: Retail inflation for farm workers eased to 5.96% in Aug; 6.08% for rural labourers
desc: Retail inflation for farm and rural workers in India eased in August, with rates dropping to 5.96% and 6.08%, respectively, from July's figures of 6.17% and 6.20%. The All-India Consumer Price Index for Agricultural Labourers and Rural Labourers increased by 7 points each, reaching levels of 1297 and 1309.

title: Is a state law hiking levy binding on central govt?
desc: States are keenly observing the Punjab-Centre conflict in the Supreme Court over state legislation raising fees for foodgrain procurement under central PDS schemes. Punjab increased the levy to 6% of MSP, while the Centre agreed to reimburse only 2%. The dispute raises questions about state versus central authority in determining procurement levies.

title: 2.5 million farmers added to PM-KISAN: Union agriculture minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan
desc: The government has introduced several farmer-friendly policies in its first 100 days, focusing on productivity, cost reduction, fair pricing, and technology use. Agriculture Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan emphasized collaboration with state governments and announced initiatives like 'Lab-to-land' to connect scientists and farmers. The PM-KISAN scheme has also disbursed ₹20,000 crore to farmers.

title: Amit Shah launches 'White Revolution 2.0' to boost dairy sector
desc: Union Minister Amit Shah has launched 'White Revolution 2.0', an initiative to transform India's dairy cooperative sector. The programme aims to empower women farmers, enhance milk production, strengthen dairy infrastructure, and boost exports. It includes the rollout of RuPay Kisan Credit Cards and micro-ATMs for dairy farmers, along with computerisation of Primary Agriculture Credit Societies.

title: Union Cabinet approves subsidy worth ₹24,475 crore on nutrient-based fertilizers
desc: The Union Cabinet has approved a ₹24,475 crore subsidy for phosphatic and potassic fertilizers to aid farmers during the rabi season. Effective from October 1, 2024, to March 31, 2025, this move aims to provide fertilizers at reasonable prices amidst global market fluctuations. The subsidy will cover 28 grades of these fertilizers.

title: Import duty on edible oils will help farmers: Union minister Chouhan
desc: The import duty on refined oils too has been increased, Chouhan noted. Besides, the government also decided to decrease the export duty on onion from 40 per cent to 20 per cent and abolished 9.5 per cent export duty on Basmati rice in the interest of the farmers, he added.

title: Global Inc comes shopping for farm fresh green cred
desc: Global companies like Microsoft, HSBC, JP Morgan, and Amazon are buying carbon credits from Indian farmers to offset their emissions. Agricultural firms such as Bayer and Grow Indigo are helping farmers adopt sustainable practices to generate these credits. India's carbon credit exports could reach $4-7 billion in the next five years, driven by increasing demand from multinational corporations.

title: Focus on youth, women, poor and farmers: PM Modi
desc: Prime Minister Narendra Modi celebrated his 74th birthday in Odisha, marking 100 days of his third term by launching the Subhadra scheme for women's welfare and other projects. He emphasized that youth, women, poor, and farmers are central to his policies. Modi also inaugurated development projects worth thousands of crores and highlighted major decisions for the welfare of various sections of society.

title: Government asks edible oil firms not to hike retail prices; 30 lakh tons oils imported at lower duty available
desc: The government has urged edible oil processors not to raise retail prices despite recent import duty hikes, citing sufficient stocks imported at lower duties. The food ministry stated that these stocks would last 45-50 days. The import duty increase aims to support domestic oilseed farmers as new crops arrive in October 2024.

title: China’s fading hunger for grain spells trouble for world farmers
desc: China's economic crisis is leading to reduced grain imports, affecting global farmers. French barley exports and US corn sales to China are down, while Australian wheat farmers brace for lower demand.

title: Duty hike on crude, refined oils to hugely benefit farmers: Official
desc: The government has increased customs duty on crude palm and refined sunflower oil to 20% and 32.5%, respectively, benefiting farmers by boosting their income. The removal of the minimum export price and reduction in export duty on onions will also aid farmers. These measures aim to support soya and oilseed farmers, particularly in Maharashtra and Madhya Pradesh, without affecting market sentiments. The changes are expected to enhance exports and farmer incomes.

title: Congress Sikh leaders defend Rahul Gandhi's remarks
desc: After BJP leaders criticised Rahul Gandhi's comments in the US about Sikhs in India, Congress fielded Sikh leaders Pratap Singh Bajwa and Charanjit Singh Channi to defend him. They questioned the BJP's handling of the farmers' agitation and claimed that Sikhs worldwide supported Gandhi's statements.

title: Haryana Polls: Farmers to up the ante against BJP
desc: Ahead of Haryana's assembly elections, farmers unions are intensifying their protests against the BJP, demanding a minimum support price guarantee legislation. Major rallies are planned in Jind and Pipli. The unions are considering various strategies to oppose the ruling party, with discussions ongoing about potential actions.

title: India cannot become developed nation with 'backward agriculture': Bayer South Asia Prez
desc: India's agriculture sector must modernize to achieve developed nation status by 2047, says Bayer South Asia head Simon Wiebusch. He commends government efforts to digitize and innovate in farming. Bayer is focusing on herbicides due to labor shortages and exploring new technologies for crops like corn and rice.

title: Govt to buy soybeans to help farmers reeling from losses
desc: India will purchase soybeans from farmers in Madhya Pradesh at government-set support prices to assist those affected by falling domestic rates. This move follows similar agreements in Maharashtra and Karnataka. Soybeans are crucial for producing soyoil, reducing edible oil imports, and generating soymeal for animal feed and export.

title: A billionaire farmer fights his jailing as tycoons face crackdown in China
desc: Chinese billionaire Sun Dawu, serving an 18-year sentence for corruption, warns that his company's collapse could impact over ten thousand employees. His case highlights President Xi Jinping's crackdown on influential tycoons seen as threats to Communist Party control. The appeal remains unheard, while his company faces new management.

title: Bajrang Punia says he will fight for women, farmers upon joining Congress
desc: Tokyo Olympics bronze medalist Bajrang Punia has joined the Congress party ahead of the Haryana Assembly elections. Punia expressed his support for women, farmers, and athletes, criticizing the BJP for not standing by them. He highlighted that Congress supported wrestlers during their protests in December 2023 without being asked.

title: Robert Vadra flays Kangana Ranaut on remarks over farmers' protest
desc: Robert Vadra, husband of Congress general secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra, criticised BJP MP Kangana Ranaut for her remarks on farmers' protests. He asserted that she does not merit a place in Parliament due to her lack of education and self-centered attitude. Vadra emphasised the urgency of addressing women's safety and called for collective action from all political parties.

title: Third eye: Leaving protestors with no effigy to burn and Chennai to Delhi: To take NEP journey or not to?
desc: In an interesting turn of events, UP police seized an effigy of BJP MP Kangana Ranaut from protesting farmer groups, leaving them to chant slogans instead. Meanwhile, letters between Chennai and Delhi continue over the National Education Policy 2020, with TN CM Stalin urging PM Modi to delink Samagra Shiksha funds from the PM-SHRI scheme.

title: SAD (Amritsar) president Simranjit Mann makes derogatory comments on Kangana Ranaut
desc: Shiromani Akali Dal (Amritsar) president Simranjit Singh Mann made derogatory remarks against BJP MP Kangana Ranaut over her controversial comments on the farmers' protest. Mann's comments came in response to a recent interview where Ranaut suggested a 'Bangladesh-like situation' could have unfolded in India without its strong leadership. Mann was attending a party event in Karnal ahead of Haryana Assembly polls on October 1.

title: AAP Punjab farmers wing holds protest, demands Kangana Ranaut's termination from Lok Sabha
desc: AAP Punjab's farmers wing protested against BJP MP Kangana Ranaut’s remarks on the farmers' protest and demanded her expulsion from the party. The protesters accused her of spreading hatred and called for legal action. The police detained protesters near the BJP office. The Himachal Pradesh Assembly also condemned her comments.

title: 'BJP's script': SP chief Akhilesh Yadav on Kangana Ranaut's remarks on farmers' protests
desc: Samajwadi Party chief Akhilesh Yadav criticized BJP MP Kangana Ranaut for her comments on the farmers' protests, claiminig that her remarks were scripted by the BJP. The BJP, distancing itself from Ranaut's statements, emphasized that she is not authorized to speak on party policies and urged her not to make such comments again.

title: Rahul Gandhi slams BJP over Kangana Ranaut's remarks, calls it grave insult to farmers of India
desc: Kangana Ranaut had posted a clip of her interview with Hindi daily Dainik Bhaskar in which she suggested that a "Bangladesh-like situation" could have erupted in India but for the country's strong leadership. She then alleged that bodies were hanging and rapes were taking place during the farmers' protest against the now-repealed three farm laws.

title: Rahul Gandhi attacks BJP over Kangana Ranaut's comment, says 'proof of anti-farmer policy'
desc: In response to Kangana Ranaut's controversial remarks on the farmer protests, Rahul Gandhi claimed the BJP's propaganda machinery disrespects farmers. He mentioned the sacrifice of 700 farmers during the 378-day protest and noted that labeling them as rapists and foreign agents underscores the BJP's anti-farmer stance and intentions.

title: On Independence Day, farmers hold tractor marches in Punjab, Haryana
desc: On Independence Day, farmers in Punjab and Haryana organized tractor marches to urge the government for a legal guarantee on Minimum Support Price (MSP) for crops. The protests, led by Samyukt Kisan Morcha and Kisan Mazdoor Morcha, aimed to bring attention to farmers' grievances over crop prices and extend their 'Delhi Chalo' campaign.

title: Sharad Pawar slams PM Modi's assurance of doubling farmers' income, claims suicides have doubled
desc: Sharad Pawar criticised the BJP government for not fulfilling its promise to double farmers' incomes, highlighting an increase in farmer suicides. Speaking in Solapur, he emphasized the plight of farmers dealing with debt and low prices. Pawar called for a change in government to better serve farmers, youth, and women.

title: Shivraj Singh Chouhan says don't treat farmers as vote bank; Congress walks out
desc: In a contentious Rajya Sabha session, Agriculture Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan and Congress members clashed over giving legal status to the Minimum Support Price (MSP). The debate intensified when Chouhan accused Congress leaders of being anti-farmer, referencing past incidents of violence against farmers. Congress members walked out in protest as Chouhan praised Prime Minister Modi's farmer welfare initiatives.
